column4: Can anybody tell me what these errors mean? http://paste.husk.org/6941
looks bad. Better back up your data and order a new hard disk.
so this is a physical thing... I can't just reformat and hope that reformatting would mark the bad sectors away?
you could do that, but I personally tend to get jittery at the slightest sign of disk trouble.
I'd rather spend a couple extra hours working for money than fiddling with unreliable hardware.
agreed
so if I try to reformat this thing remotely (the machine is about 1 hr drive away), is it possible it could hard lock on me again?
of course it's possible. How are you going to reformat -- with badblocks checking?
was thinking ext3 maybe
you can try 'mke2fs -c -c -j /dev/hdcX' to have the best chance of fixing things. But really, bad blocks occurring in a newer hard disk is a sign of impending doom ;)
reinstalling is your best option. Doesn't take long, and you can backup your /home
sorry, got cut off
I'm generally much in favour of fresh installations -- what's stopping you from doing that?
I have alot of stuff installed on here and I really do not want to have to reinstall. besides it sucks to have to reinstall. this is not windows.
you can save your package list (see clone factoid below), and keep your old installation around if you have enough HD space
I understand your reservations about reinstalling, but Ubuntu evolves in such a way that it's sometimes beneficial to reinstall
remember  the old  adage, data you haven't backed up is data you don't want
I agree. sound advice. my quesiton still stands. can an upgrade make my data inaccessible? I thought that I could always boot a linux cd and mount the ext3 drive, in the worst case scenario.
probably, yes. There are operations, however, that can make your partitions inaccessible if there's e.g. a power cut at precisely the wrong moment
like partition resizing
yw
